0.text:
You don't need 4K says Sony. 
Have this  audiophile Blu-ray player instead.

12.text: In this plain white box is the Sony H1. It's not in its standard retail

17.text: packaging because it's an early sample shipped from Sony Japan.

26.text:
It comes with a cryptic message. 
No idea what that means.

34.text: Everything on the inside though is what you'll get when you buy one.

46.text: The power lead is captive, which as you can see is a bit of a nuisance.

56.text:
As this is an early sample, the instruction
booklet supplied is a photocopy.

76.text: Let's take a look at the back panel. There's Ethernet, twin HDMI outputs, plus digital

82.text: audio, and a pair of stereo phonos. Notice the stereo phonos are widely spaced, so you can use chunky, high quality cables.

93.text: The two HDMIs are for separate audio and video use, to maximise sonic performance.

100.text:
The finish on the deck is great. You have
to go back to the old Sony ES model from 2009

106.text:
to find something as well crafted as this.
The top panel is made from a textured ABS,

112.text: and has a really premium feel.

115.text:
Obviously there's Wi-Fi on board, in fact
it has two aerials in a Mimo configuration.

121.text: It's also got Bluetooth. The Bluetooth module is behind the Sony badge on the fascia, the

127.text: Wi-Fi aerials are to the right.

131.text: In case you're in any doubt,  there's a badge to show this is part of Sony's Hi-Res Audio family...love that finish.

139.text: Flip the deck over, and you'll see that there are four anti-vibration feet.

144.text: Look closer and you'll see they sit on embossed ribs which offer additional isolation. Attention to detail

153.text: Overall I think build quality is a big improvement over what we've seen on past Sony Blu-ray players.

163.text: The deck is built around a sturdy chassis, note the two vertical beams which keep things rigid.

169.text: File support across a network is good. The deck will play MKVs, FLAC and DSD.

176.text: The disc transport is universal, and can play both SACDs and DVD Audio, in addition to all the

183.text:
The H1 may not play 4K discs, but there's
no shortage of streaming apps onboard, including

189.text: Netflix, Amazon, BBC iPlayer, YouTube, Spotify.

194.text: There's a tonne of picture processing modes,

197.text: including a new 16-bit version of Super Bit Mapping. This is Sony technology to remove colour banding.

206.text:
This isn't intended to be a review, but I
will say picture and audio quality are fantastic on this player

213.text: Out of interest I did a shootout between this player and the Samsung 4K deck using 'San Andreas'

218.text: and aside from HDR grading there wasn't a huge difference in picture clarity between the two models.

229.text: The deck upscales to 2160/60 with 4:4:4 colour.

234.text: There's also Sony's own movies on demand service here, as well as PlayStation Now.

239.text: Yes, the deck really does work with a Dual Shock controller.

244.text:
So that's the UHP-H1. I think it's a little
bit brilliant. It may not be UHD but it's

248.text:
the best Sony Blu-ray player for ages and
gives an idea what Sony's first 4K deck will

254.text:
actually be like, as the same dev team are
working on it.
